content: How can I help you today?

I’ve just been really struggling to sleep, and it’s starting to wear me down. There’s a lot going on at work, and I can’t stop stressing about it when I’m supposed to be winding down at night. It’s hard to shut my mind off.

That sounds really exhausting, dealing with both work stress and difficulty sleeping. Stress can have such a big impact, especially when it interferes with rest that your body and mind need. You’ve been carrying a lot—how are you managing with everything?

Honestly, I don’t think I’m managing it very well. I just feel stuck in this cycle. At night, I’ll try to distract myself with my phone to stop the racing thoughts, but it only seems to make things worse.

It sounds like you're trying to find ways to deal with the racing thoughts, but they just keep coming back, leaving you feeling stuck and frustrated. Managing stress like this can be so challenging. What do you think has been making it hardest for you to break this cycle?

I think it’s just that I can’t stop worrying—about work, money, being there for my family. It feels like as soon as I try to relax, all these thoughts just flood in, and I don’t know how to turn them off.

That sounds overwhelming—having so much on your mind every time you try to relax. Balancing worries about work, finances, and your family all at once can feel like a heavy weight. What’s most important to you right now as you think about these different areas of your life?

If I had to pick, I think my family is the most important. I want to be a good partner and a good parent, and I feel like all of this stress is making it harder to be present for them. I just want to be a reliable provider and a role model, but sometimes it feels like I’m failing at both.

It sounds like your family means a lot to you, and you want to give them your best. You seem to have strong values—being present, providing for them, and being a role model—but the stress you're experiencing is making it hard to show up in the way you'd like. What do you think your family would say about how you're doing?

I’m not sure. My partner keeps telling me that I’m doing enough and that they’re proud of me, but it’s hard to believe when I feel like I’m not meeting my own expectations. My kids are too young to really understand, but I don’t want them to feel like I’m distant or distracted all the time. I just want to be better for them.

It sounds like your partner sees your efforts and believes in you, even when you're feeling unsure about yourself. And your love for your kids shines through in how much you care about being present for them. You seem to have high expectations for yourself—it’s clear you want to give them the very best of you. What would "being better" for your family look like in your eyes?

For me, it would mean being more present with them—having the energy to play with my kids, the patience to handle tough moments, and the ability to just enjoy our time together without my mind wandering to work or stress. I just don’t want them to feel like I’m distracted or not fully there with them.

You have a clear picture of the kind of parent and partner you want to be—present, patient, and able to fully enjoy those moments with your family. It sounds like feeling overwhelmed is the barrier between where you are and where you want to be. Where do you think you could start to create space for those moments of presence and enjoyment?
Sorry, I think I'm okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
